8.text:
Hi I’m Alison Taafe, the Sassy Chef, thanks
for joining us. We’re going to show you

12.text:
some delightful snacks that will sell in your
tuckshop and they are going to be healthy

16.text: as well. So we’re going to make some smart choices today with the snacks that we’re

19.text:
going to do. First of all I’m going to make
a fantastic muesli bar which everybody will

23.text: love and utilising some oats and some seeds and cinnamon, some lovely flavours, and then

28.text:
I’m going to make some apple and sultana
muffins as well which are guaranteed success.

32.text:
My husband says he doesn’t like muffins
but he loved those when I made them yesterday

36.text:
so that’s great. Also I’m going to make
some really good snacks like little crudités,

39.text:
little sticks of vegetables with a lovely
tzatziki mint and yoghurt dip as well so let’s

43.text: get cracking. I’m going to add three cups of dried rolled

47.text:
oats to my bowl and in the same bowl I’m
going to add seeds. I’ve got sunflower seeds

52.text:
and I’ve got pepita kernels, so pumpkin
seeds as well which make a really lovely crunchiness

56.text: to this bar. There’s going to be some cinnamon in there so one teaspoon of cinnamon. You

61.text:
can put nutmeg in or allspice or whatever
spice you have. Now to get this all bound

66.text:
nicely we’re going to add three quarters
of a cup of honey. Now I’ve just softened

69.text:
that honey so you can see how easy it is to
just pour. So just pop the bottle into some

73.text:
boiling water to let it stand or if you’re
worried about it sticking to your jug, put

78.text: boiling water in your jug first, fill it, tip it out, then put the honey in, the honey

82.text:
just falls straight out. So much easier. I’ve
also got some olive oil so half a cup of olive

87.text: oil going in there to bind as well and vanilla. I’m using vanilla extract; it’s much better

93.text:
then vanilla essence which is kind of like
a science, science class in a bottle when

98.text: you use essence. You’re not quite sure what’s in there but with extract you know what’s

102.text: in there. It’s just pure vanilla. It’s lovely. So pop a little bit of that in, about

104.text:
a teaspoon of extract and then to bind all
this together which at the moment is probably

111.text:
not going to happen without the addition of
some eggs. We’re going to add some eggs

114.text:
to it so three eggs are going in and I’m
going to beat those eggs up a little bit first as well.

129.text: Make sure you beat them up really well so

130.text:
that when you mix them through the muesli
you’re not going to have great bit lumps

132.text:
of egg white showing. This is just to bind
the ingredients to it moistens them and also

137.text:
helps the muesli bars to set so that they’re
nice and easy for you to cut up when you’re

140.text:
going to sell them. So give this a nice beat,
make sure it’s all beaten well and then

145.text: add that into the same bowl. Very simple this recipe. Very simple. So take a spoon and just

152.text:
give that a really good mix and make sure
that all the oats and all the seeds are completely

158.text:
covered with moisture, being the oil, the
honey and the eggs.

162.text:
So once you get it like so – it smells nice,
you can smell that lovely cinnamon in there,

167.text:
really beautiful. Alright so easy right? Five
minutes, not even. Take a bowl or a dish around

172.text:
about this size. You’ll soon know when you
push the muesli into the dish that it’s

177.text: going to need to be about probably one and a half to two centimetres deep. So you don't want a great big long tray

182.text: make it too thin so try and restrict it to a size around about like the one I’m using here.

187.text: It’s probably around about 30 centimetres by about, probably not even that.

190.text: Probably say 22 centimetres long by about 12 centimetres wide. That’s just me guessing.

201.text: and at the moment it’s a bit sloppy so what we need to do is

203.text: pop that in the oven for around about 20 to 25 minutes and the oven temperature

208.text:
needs to be quite low though so we’re only
looking at 150 degrees Celsius. We don't really

212.text:
want that to colour, we just want it to set.
So the eggs start to set, the coagulation

216.text: happens around the oats, makes fantastic muesli bars. So I’m just going to pop that in the

220.text:
oven, the oven is preheated to 150 degrees
Celsius.

226.text: So these are out of the oven now. Just a little tip when they’re in the oven just make sure

230.text:
they’re not browning too much. If you see
a little bit around the edges, you can’t

233.text: help that because that’s the honey caramelising but realistically this should come out almost

237.text:
the same as it goes in. The only difference
is that it’s set. You can feel it. When

241.text:
it’s in the oven through it’s still a
little bit soft because it’s still warm.

244.text: You have to make sure that you cool it down. So it’s much better to make this early,

248.text:
stick it in the fridge so it can get firm
before you cut it.

251.text: So the idea is now I’m going to use a serrated edge knife so that I can cut these muesli

254.text:
bars nice and straight and I can saw down
through those seeds as well. Now you can cut

260.text:
these in any sizes you want, it just depends
on the size that you’d like to give and

266.text:
the price that you’d like to charge for
it really. Okay so look, you can see that

270.text:
this stays together reasonably well and it’s
like a – my mum used to make these and we

274.text:
used to call them flapjacks in England, a
little bit the same.

276.text: So what I’m going to do is just pop that on the board.

278.text: I’m going to cut that down into two pieces and just pop that on the plate so you can see how delightful they look.

299.text: I’m going to take one of these little bars and I’m just going to pop that into some wrap paper.

309.text: You can always take a little bit of the muesli bar out at the end as well if you wish

325.text: and you can tie that with a little bit of string which makes it look quite nice as well, so.

338.text: I’ll just pop that just up on there as well so a really lovely snack, really good.

341.text: So very easy, takes five minutes to make, 15 to 20 minutes in the oven.

345.text: Make sure you make them in advance because you need to make sure they set

348.text: so when you cut them up you get some nice shapes out of them as well. That one is really easy.

352.text: Next up I’m going to do an apple and sultana muffin which is guaranteed to be a crowd pleaser.

358.text: Okay so now onto our second snack, our healthy snacks,

361.text: we are going to do some apple and sultana muffins you are going to really love

364.text:
this one it just takes one bowl, mix it up,
put it in the oven and everybody is going

368.text: to love it. Okay so let’s get on with these muffins.

371.text:
We’re going to take 125 grams of melted
unsalted butter,

374.text: just melt it in the microwave or in a small pan.

377.text: We’re also going to add our milk which is 200 mls of light skim milk,

383.text: half a cup of raw sugar,

388.text: Give that a little bit of a mix up first.

400.text: So basically all of the wet ingredients go in together with the sugar first, get that little bit mixed up.

404.text: Make almost like a batter, this recipe. So you add your one extra large egg.

414.text:
The next stage is going to be adding flour
and I do add cinnamon to this too so I normally

417.text: put the cinnamon, add a couple of spoons of cinnamon, normally mix it with the flour because

421.text:
I’m going to sieve the flour into this recipe.
Sieving not only will get rid of the lumps

426.text:
but it will also aerate this recipe. We are
using self raising flour anyway so we are

431.text:
going to get a nice light muffin. I’m going
to add this half at a time, so add half first,

436.text: mix – this is where the whisk might come in handy guys. You might find that whisking

440.text:
that in helps you to get a nice lump free
batter. Yep so just gradually so maybe into

446.text: two or even three goes, that way the cinnamon and the flour mix together nicely. So what

452.text:
you should have is a reasonably stiff batter
at this stage.

456.text:
Alright now right at the moment this is just
a base mixture. You could put anything into

460.text: this mix, any sort of dried fruit is appropriate, any fruit, anything you’d like, and today

464.text:
I’m choosing to use apples. Now apples,
granny smith apples are better, they’re

469.text:
less sugar. If you’re going to use a fresh
apple, peel it, core it, cut it into quarters,

473.text:
core it and cut it into nice reasonable size
dice and you might need a little bit of lemon

476.text:
juice on it if you’re going to do this in
advance because otherwise it’s going to

479.text: go brown which you probably already know. Or, make it even easier, you can use canned

484.text: apples and they’re pretty much already mushed up as well. They’re supposed to be sliced

487.text: but in the can you’ll notice that they are a little bit broken sometimes which is great

491.text:
for this recipe. So I’m going to add those.
You’ll notice they’ve been drained so

495.text:
don't put all the liquid in from the can as
well and make these muffins too wet.

498.text:
I’m just going to add some sultanas and
now also this could be changed with dates

502.text: or even raisins or even dried apricots, whatever you’d like, pop those in as well. Then I

508.text:
suggest you change implements to stir this
through at the end. But you stir that through,

514.text: so careful not to break up the apple too much because it is a little bit soft, and you can

517.text: see you’ve got almost just like a cake mixture here which is lovely. So just mix that through,

522.text:
almost like fold it through really at the
end. So the self raising flour makes sure

525.text:
that these muffins are lovely and light as
you can see I’ve got some that I’ve made

529.text:
earlier, they’re just beautiful and they’re
really moist as well and that’s because

532.text:
of the apple that’s in them. It keeps its
moisture nicely.

535.text:
You can use a variety of little cupcakes,
little patty moulds, I chose green ones because

540.text:
it matches the apple, you know I’m all for
that. But I’ve also got these really lovely

544.text:
ones, they are – normally you see these
in coffee shops. They look very glamorous.

547.text:
They really are just bits of paper folded
up. You could make a fortune if you went into

550.text:
this business. You can pop those straight
into the muffin trays and you don't need to

555.text:
spray them, don't need to line them so it
makes them so much easier, it helps with the

558.text: washing up as well. You can buy brown ones and you can also buy white but if all else

563.text: fails how about just using the good old fashioned little cupcake cups, just like so.

568.text:
I’ll do a couple like that just so you can see
the difference.

571.text:
Alright now when you’re going to use this
mix, I would suggest two spoons and I would

577.text: suggest going quite slowly because especially if you get the mixture up on the top of those

582.text:
muffin patty cases. So just take a spoon of
the mix, drop it in over the centre, and then

587.text:
it allows you to do that so that you don't
spill the muffin mix anywhere else. So spoon

593.text:
it off the other spoon, much easier. I’ll
show you in one of these shallow ones so you

596.text:
can see what I’m saying, and that way you
can control it more when it goes in. So two

602.text:
good spoonfuls in each one, so that’s a
good portion control as well as a help to

606.text:
get it into the dish, and what we’re going
to do is just make the tops a little bit crunchy.

614.text:
We’re going to add a little bit of raw sugar,
a little bit of cinnamon and also I thought

619.text: we might put some oats on the top. It makes it look really earthy, gives us another nutrient

624.text: in this dish as well but it also helps to make it crunchy on the top. We all love the

628.text: tops of muffins. There was a television series on about people buying just muffin tops because

633.text:
no-one is really interested in the bottom,
they just like the top. So we’re going to

636.text:
make the top really, really crunchy and very
decadent. Being healthy at the same time.

643.text:
Okay now this mixture that I’ve given you
here, this recipe will make you 12 decent

648.text:
size apple and sultana muffins. Just while
you’re finishing off your little moulds

654.text: here, just be mindful that you need to preheat your oven to around about 190 degrees Celsius.

660.text: These need to go into a warmed oven and they take around about 15 to 20 minutes to cook.

664.text: I’m going to put a few little oats on the top. You don't have to do this, you can just

668.text:
leave them as they are but it does make it
a little bit crunchier and gives it a little

671.text:
bit more interest. They look nice as well.
A little bit of brown sugar – not brown

680.text:
sugar, I mean raw sugar I should say, and
likewise you don't have to do this, I just

684.text: like to do it, and I’m just going to grab a little bit of cinnamon and just dust the

688.text: tops with cinnamon as well. Beautiful. So you can’t complain about the amount of

693.text: work going into this one, it’s like five minutes. It’s one bowl. Yes it’s a whisk

697.text:
and a spoon but that’s it. You even don't
have to wash up these muffin tins, you can

700.text: just wipe them out, they’re fine. So easy and healthy and beautiful at the same time

705.text:
so we’re going to pop those in the oven
and I’ll be back soon.

709.text:
Okay so we’ve got our lovely muffins out
of the oven. They smell glorious, they’re

713.text: so nice. Who can resist a hot cake or muffin out of the oven? Now just to make sure that

719.text:
they are cooked, I’ll give you a couple
of little pointers. The first thing to do

722.text:
is to just press the centre of the cake and
make sure it springs back up to the touch.

726.text:
So in other words the mixture in the centre
of the cake is not still wet. If it was your

729.text: thumb would stay down, the thumb print would stay down in the cake, it would still be wet

733.text:
inside which is not good. Another thing you
can do is take one out of the tray and with

738.text: the skewer, a wooden skewer if you can, just pop that into the cake or the muffin and remove

744.text:
it and it should be reasonably clean. If it’s
covered in wet soggy mixture, chances are

750.text:
the cakes and muffins are still wet inside
which is what we want to try and avoid it.

753.text:
So once you’re happy that they’re cooked,
they’re coloured nicely, not too dark, so

757.text: around about 15 to 20 minutes, pop them onto a rack because the reason we use the rack

762.text: is that we want to make sure that the air is circulating underneath. If we leave them

766.text:
in the muffin trays then they’re going to
get a little bit soggy, a little bit damp,

770.text: a bit of condensation, so that’s a good tip.

778.text: Beautiful, so there’s our apple and sultana muffins ready to eat, looking great,

781.text: and a nice healthy snack for your tuckshops.

785.text:
So now we’re going to do our tzatziki and
vegetable batons or vegetable crudités, some

791.text:
people might say ‘crudites’ but it’s
actually crudités and it sounds better, it’s

794.text:
all in the name. So we’re going to do some
batons of raw vegetables. I’ve got capsicum,

799.text: cucumber, celery and carrot to use. Then I’m going to use a natural yoghurt, put some mint

803.text:
and lemon juice in and make a tzatziki with
a bit of garlic. So these are really healthy

807.text: snacks for your tuckshop. So what I was going to do is just cut up a

811.text:
little bit of vegetable. And we’ve got some
nice celery there, some young celery in the

815.text:
inside, and I’ve got some carrots here that
I’m going to cut into my batons and what

821.text:
I want you to do is cut your strips of carrot
first, keep them nice and chunky, and what

828.text:
I do is cut down so that you have a base to
cut on and then therefore the carrot is not

833.text:
rolling all over the bench which sometimes
is difficult to cut.

838.text: Okay so with this, now sometimes with a cucumber it’s nice to take the seeds out. Not everybody

843.text:
likes the seeds. So I normally just cut the
seeds out a little bit and cut the strips.

849.text: So I still leave the peel on, I don't peel it, that’s a little bit more nutrients there

852.text: for us but yeah, it’s up to you if you want to leave the seeds in. I’m using a Lebanese

858.text:
cucumber so that it’s a little bit sweeter.
Alternatively you could use a continental

862.text: cucumber, one of the larger ones. So we want a nice bite size piece to go in this dish.

868.text:
I’m just going to cut my batons of carrot
as well. Try and keep them all the same length

872.text:
so they look nice, nice and neat, and if you
want to you can pop a little bit of cherry

877.text: tomato in these as well as a little crudités, it doesn’t all have to be sticks, and you

880.text: can also use some raw broccoli and raw cauliflower which is also very nutritious. People might

884.text:
turn their nose up at easing raw cauliflower
but it’s actually the best way to eat it.

889.text: So cut it into smaller pieces for people. Okay so we’ve got our carrots and our cucumber.

894.text:
I’m going to use a little bit of this celery
here and I’m just going to take the younger

898.text:
pieces of celery, it’s not nice using the
outside celery leaves and celery stalks because

902.text:
they can be a little bit tough to chew. So
take a little bit of red capsicum, cut down

908.text:
each side allowing the seeds to fall out and
you might want to cut away a little bit of

913.text: the centre pith as well because it can be a little bit bitter.

917.text: So this one you’re restricted by the length of the capsicum so you can’t really change

922.text:
that too much but if you have a big enough
capsicum it makes a decent size crudités

928.text: anyway. Just add a little bit of green capsicum as well. So cut down each side when you’re

933.text: doing this and it leaves the centre seeds in there which is okay. If they fall out, just brush them away.

943.text: Alright so if you wanted to use a cup to put the crudités in

947.text: put the tzatziki at the bottom and build the crudités up so every piece has a little

951.text: bit on its bottom, or you can use one of your normal plastic containers with a small container

956.text: for the dip. It’s entirely up to you and also it depends on the type of packaging that

960.text: you can get hold of. So I’m going to do it in both so that you can see the difference today.

965.text: So I’m taking some natural yoghurt, it’s been unsweetened,

968.text: just a natural thick set yoghurt,

972.text: and what I’m going to do is add a little bit of seasoning to this,

976.text: a tiny pinch of salt and some black pepper,

982.text: and I’m going to chop a little bit of mint to go in this.

990.text: I’ve got some fresh mint ready to go here; I’m just going to give that a nice chop.

994.text: So just gently, just nicely, it doesn’t matter if it’s a little bit chunky,

1001.text: just a nice chop and pop that straight into the yoghurt.

1015.text: Okay so now we need to add a little bit of lemon juice as well.

1022.text: and take a spoon and just mix it through,

1024.text: and of course you can check the seasoning and check that you’ve got enough mint in there as well.

1028.text: But yeah, you want it to be nice and colourful, nice and lively flavour wise.

1032.text: Now have a little taste, yeah good. We also want to keep it nice and fresh so not too much

1038.text: salt and pepper in there, not too overwhelming with flavour, and possibly a little bit more

1043.text:
of the lemon, and the only other thing that
I would like to put in there is some garlic,

1049.text:
some raw garlic, but if you think that’s
a little bit too strong then you can leave

1053.text: it out but I prefer to put a little bit of minced garlic through this as well as a traditional

1057.text:
tzatziki. The Greeks would be screaming at
me now, they’d say it’s always in there,

1061.text: it’s basically a lemon and yoghurt and garlic dip so yeah it’s pretty much always in there

1067.text:
but it’s up to you what you prefer. So we’re
just going to chop a little bit of fresh garlic

1071.text:
and of course you can use a garlic mincer,
which is a little garlic press, if you wish.

1075.text:
Entirely up to you, whatever is easiest and
fastest for you. This time we need the garlic

1078.text:
to go a little bit finer than before. There’s
nothing worse than getting a big chunk of

1082.text:
raw garlic in your mouth but the flavour of
that through there just freshens it all up

1087.text:
and gives it that lovely little taste as well.
So, but it’s entirely your choice. It depends

1092.text:
whether you want to have garlic breath or
not for the rest of the day I suppose.

1095.text:
So what we’d like to do is just pop a little
bit of that into our little container

1101.text: and you don't need to fill it up, you can just sort of like maybe put two spoons in there for one serve,

1105.text: otherwise you’ll end up with all the yoghurt being wasted so you don't need too much.

1109.text: And in the cup, we’re going to put a little bit at the bottom of the cup,

1116.text: maybe just two spoons just like before

1118.text: and then what I thought I’d do is just pop some of this veg into the cup,

1123.text: put some of the longer pieces up,

1136.text: and of course some of the cucumber.

1138.text: A really cool way of serving that.

1141.text: Okay and in here I’ve got my carrots and my celery, really lovely and not very expensive.

1147.text: It’s obviously nice to have a lot of vegetables and stuff but it’s also very easy to prepare.

1151.text: So save a little bit of time and have all the vegetables cut up in advance.

1155.text: Don't put them in water though, don't leave them in water because they’ll lose all their nutrients,

1159.text: cut them up and use them straightaway.

1161.text: Pop them into your container and then pop a lid on, we could even put a little bit of mint

1165.text: on there as a bit of a garnish just to freshen it all up and I’m sure that when they see

1170.text:
that in the tuckshop they’re probably going
to buy it because a lot of kids these days

1173.text:
love raw vegetables as opposed to cooked.
Get some raw veggies into them with a nice

1177.text:
dip and have a very healthy alternative in
our tuckshops.

1181.text: So thanks very much and don't forget

1182.text: all of these recipes are available on the Smart Choices website.
